channel.title: Bloomberg Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Beyond Nvidia, Four Things to Know at Asia’s Biggest Tech Show
item.description: Nvidia Corp.’s Jensen Huang headlines the 2025 edition of Asia’s biggest electronics conference, for years a showcase for his company’s cutting-edge AI chips and the companies lining up to buy them. This year, however, the spotlight may well be on another far bigger personality: US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov, Jane Lanhee Lee

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, Nvidia CEO

item.title: Nvidia CEO Sees No Evidence of AI Chip Diversion Into China
item.description: Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang expressed confidence in his company’s trade partners and said there’s no evidence of its prized semiconductors being diverted to the Chinese market.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Droulers

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nvidia Corp., speaks during a news conference at the Nvidia GPU Technology Conference (GTC) in San Jose, California, US, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. Nvidia Corp., whose products have fueled a flood of artificial intelligence spending, said new types of AI models that produce more complex answers will only increase the need for computing infrastructure. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: OpenAI, Oracle to Help UAE Develop Massive Data Center
item.description: OpenAI plans to help develop a massive new data center in the United Arab Emirates that may eventually be one of the largest in the world, a major bet on the Middle East and a significant expansion of the company’s global AI infrastructure ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Shirin Ghaffary, Dina Bass, Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: The OpenAI logo on a laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 12, 2023. Microsoft Corp. is in discussions to invest as much as $10 billion in OpenAI, the creator of viral artificial intelligence bot ChatGPT, according to people familiar with its plans. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Epic Asks Court to Force Apple to Approve Fortnite on US Store
item.description: Epic Games Inc. asked a court to force Apple Inc. to approve access to the hit game Fortnite in the US App Store, the latest tussle in a long-running feud over Apple’s control of game distribution revenue.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: The Epic Games Inc. Fortnite: Battle Royale video game is displayed for a photograph on an Apple Inc. iPhone in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Thursday, May 10, 2018. Fortnite, the hit game that's denting the stock prices of video-game makers after signing up 45 million players, didn't really take off until it became free and a free-for-all. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

item.title: Tesla Moves to Stymie Shareholder Lawsuits After Musk Pay Saga
item.description: Tesla Inc. took a step to prevent future shareholder lawsuits like the one that blocked a record-setting pay package for Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: Rick Clough, Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., arrives at court during the SolarCity trial in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S., on Tuesday, July 13, 2021. Musk was cool but combative as he testified in a Delaware courtroom that Tesla's more than $2 billion acquisition of SolarCity in 2016 wasn't a bailout of the struggling solar provider.

item.title: CoreWeave Jumps to Record After Nvidia Reports Larger Stake
item.description: CoreWeave Inc. shares surged 22% to a record high on Friday after Nvidia Corp. reported a larger-than-anticipated stake in the cloud-computing provider.
item.dc:creator: Nick Turner, Jeran Wittenstein

media:content.media:description: CoreWeave Inc. signage in Times Square in New York, US, on Friday, May 9, 2025. After a heavily scaled down initial public offering, CoreWeave Inc. is in discussions to raise about $1.5 billion in debt, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: Coinbase Boosted by S&P 500 Inclusion Despite Hack, Probe Risks
item.description: Coinbase Global Inc.’s rally has been unconquerable this week, as even a one-two punch of negative headlines did little to stop the crypto exchange operator’s climb ahead of its inclusion in the S&P 500 Index.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: Monitors display Coinbase signage during the company's initial public offering (IPO) at the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, April 14, 2021. Coinbase Global Inc., the largest U.S. cryptocurrency exchange, is set to debut on Wednesday through a direct listing, an alternative to a traditional initial public offering that has only been deployed a handful of times. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Charter and Cox Combine in $34.5 Billion Cable Deal
item.description: Charter Communications and Cox Communications, two of the largest US cable providers, agree to combine in a deal worth $34.5 billion. Bloomberg’s Michelle Davis explains why this deal has been years in the making, speaking with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Prosus CEO Defends Offer for Just Eat Takeaway
item.description: Prosus CEO Fabricio Bloisi explains how the company is using M&A in its ambition to become the biggest tech lifestyle company outside the US and Asia. Bloisi joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Verizon Wins FCC Nod for Frontier Deal After Ditching DEI
item.description: Verizon Communications Inc. won Federal Communications Commission approval for its $9.6 billion acquisition of Frontier Communications Parent Inc. after agreeing to agency demands to pare back diversity initiatives in line with President Donald Trump’s policies.
item.dc:creator: Kelcee Griffis

media:content.media:description: Brendan Carr, commissioner at the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), speaks during the Semafor Innovating to Restore Trust in News Summit in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. The summit, which is gathering leaders from across the media industry, is looking to reimagine the future of news and rebuild public trust in media.

item.title: Airbnb Aims to Boost Revenue with New Services, Ads
item.description: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky discusses why the vacation rental company overhauled its app and is refocusing on events and services. Chesky outlines the revenue opportunities for Airbnb with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Amazon Removed Backup Landing Sensors Before Drone Crashes
item.description: Retaining the technology could have prevented the aircraft from accidentally shutting off their propellers midflight and plummeting to the ground.
item.dc:creator: Matt Day

media:content.media:description: An Amazon MK30 delivery drone.

item.title: Microsoft Will Need to Take on OpenAI to Hit AI Goals
item.description: Bloomberg’s Austin Carr discusses his conversation with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella and why the tech boss says AI will remake every business. Carr joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Coinbase Hack Could Have Wide-Ranging Impact
item.description: Crypto trading platform Coinbase said a hacker demanded $20 million to delete illegally obtained customer data. Bloomberg’s Margi Murphy explains how the hacker gained access to Coinbase's customer information and the potential cost of the incident. She speaks with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Globant Suffers Record Intraday Drop as Tariffs Dent Earnings
item.description: Software company Globant SA suffered a record intraday decline after blaming its disappointing first-quarter results on the ripple effects of US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Globant headquarters in Montevideo, Uruguay. Photographer: Ana Ferreira/Bloomberg

item.title: Tech Investors Digest Trump’s Week in the Middle East
item.description: Ipek Ozkardeskaya, Swissquote Senior Analyst, discusses how markets are reacting to tech deals announced during President Trump’s visit to the Gulf. She joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Coinbase Hack Highlights How Greed Can Overwhelm Cyber Defenses
item.description: Following cybersecurity best practices doesn’t always protect against human greed.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Stone

media:content.media:description: The Coinbase logo on a laptop computer arranged in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, U.S., on Tuesday, Jan. 5, 2021. Coinbase Inc. knew cryptocurrency XRP was a security rather than a commodity and "illegally" sold Ripple Labs Inc.'s tokens anyway, a customer argues in a proposed class-action lawsuit over the commissions the crypto exchange collected.

item.title: Cinven Taps Goldman, UBS for €6 Billion Ufinet Sale
item.description: Private equity firm Cinven has selected Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and UBS Group AG to arrange a sale of telecom operator Ufinet Group, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga, Vinicy Chan, Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: Light trails from network switches illuminate fiber optic cables, center, and copper Ethernet cables inside a communications room at an office in London, U.K., on Monday, May 21, 2018. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport will work with the Home Office to publish a white paper later this year setting out legislation, according to a statement, which will also seek to force tech giants to reveal how they target abusive and illegal online material posted by users. Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Week in the Gulf, Airbnb's App Redesign | Bloomberg Technology
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss President Trump’s tech-focused trip to the Middle East. Plus, Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky explains the revenue opportunity the company sees in services as it launches a redesigned app. And Prosus CEO Fabricio Bloisi says partnerships and acquisitions are part of the company’s efforts to become the biggest tech lifestyle company outside the US or China. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Video Game Makers Turn Back to Kickstarter in Tough Funding Climate
item.description: With investors closing their wallets, some indie studios are once again looking to crowdfunding
item.dc:creator: Jason Schreier

media:content.media:description: The makers of 2023’s Stray Gods, nominated for a Grammy, are looking to Kickstarter for their next game.

item.title: FTC Rests at Meta Monopoly Trial, Shifting Focus to Defense
item.description: The Federal Trade Commission wrapped up its case Thursday for breaking up Meta Platforms Inc. as an illegal social-media monopoly, with the company now set to lay out its defense in the ongoing antitrust trial.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco

media:content.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive officer of Meta Platforms Inc., arrives at federal court in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. The Federal Trade Commission alleges the acquisitions of Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 have given the company now known as Meta Platforms Inc. a social media monopoly, and is fighting to break up the company.

item.title: Coinbase Hackers Use Bribery to Grease the Wheels to Access Client Data
item.dc:creator: Jeff Stone

media:content.media:description: Brian Armstrong, chief executive officer of Coinbase Global Inc., speaks during a "Stand With Crypto" get out the vote rally at The Bourbon Room in Los Angeles, California, US, on Monday, March 4, 2024. California's Senate race is living up to its jungle primary nickname and turning out to be one of the most competitive in the nation, featuring crypto billionaire donors and a former star baseball player.

item.title: European Stocks Post Fifth Week of Gains as Trade Tensions Ease
item.description: European stocks wrapped up a fifth straight week of gains with investors focused on US trade negotiations, while the corporate earnings season has turned out better than expected.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: Stock prices on the trading floor of the Euronext NV stock exchange in Paris, France, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Stocks rose as US President Donald Trump floated a potential pause in auto tariffs, providing further relief to the market after he suspended levies on some consumer electronics. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: OpenAI Takes on Google, Anthropic With New AI Agent for Coders
item.description: OpenAI is rolling out a new artificial intelligence agent for ChatGPT users that’s designed to help streamline software development as the company pushes into a crowded market of startups and large tech firms offering AI tools for coders.
item.dc:creator: Shirin Ghaffary

media:content.media:description: OpenAI on the Apple Safari app on a laptop arranged in Germantown, New York, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Apple Inc. is "actively looking at" revamping the Safari web browser on its devices to focus on AI-powered search engines, a seismic shift for the industry hastened by the potential end of a longtime partnership with Google.

item.title: Applied Materials Slides After Giving Disappointing Forecast
item.description: Applied Materials Inc. shares fell as much as 7.3% after the chip-equipment maker gave a lackluster forecast for the current period, highlighting the potential cost of the US trade dispute with China.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Signage outside Applied Materials headquarters in Santa Clara, California, U.S., on Thursday, May 13, 2021. Applied Materials Inc. is expected to release earnings figures on May 20. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Premier League Sponsors Exit UK After Gaming Watchdog Probe
item.description: Six betting websites that sponsor UK Premier League football clubs have ceased their UK operations after an investigation by the country’s gambling regulator into their licensing partner.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Solon, David Hellier

media:content.media:description: Marcus Tavernier of Bournemouth in action.

item.title: Ratos Weighs IPO of Nordic Construction Unit Sentia
item.description: Swedish conglomerate Ratos AB is considering listing its construction arm Sentia, according to people familiar with the matter, marking another potential initial public offering for the Nordic region.
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro

media:content.media:description: A crane stands silhouetted at sunrise on a construction site at a Samsung Electronics Co. semiconductor plant in Pyeongtaek, Gyeonggi Province, South Korea, on Saturday, Oct. 27, 2018. Samsung is scheduled to release third-quarter earnings results on Oct. 31. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Nvidia Shares Roar Back as Clouds Hanging Over Chipmaker Fade
item.description: After several months in the wilderness, Nvidia Corp. shares have found their way again as doubts about Big Tech spending subside, trade tensions with China ease, and new chip buyers emerge.
item.dc:creator: Jeran Wittenstein, Ryan Vlastelica

media:content.media:description: Nvidia Corp. signage during the Nvidia GPU Technology Conference (GTC) in San Jose, California, US, on Thursday, March 20, 2025. Nvidia Corp., whose products have fueled a flood of artificial intelligence spending, said new types of AI models that produce more complex answers will only increase the need for computing infrastructure.

item.title: Pinterest Is in Talks to Lease Offices at NYC’s 11 Madison Tower
item.description: Pinterest Inc. is in talks to take office space at Manhattan’s 11 Madison Ave.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian walks past the Eleven Madison building in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, April 17, 2012. The Metropolitan Life North Building, now known as Eleven Madison, is a 30-story art deco skyscraper designed in the 1920s by Harvey Wiley Corbett and D. Everett Waid.

item.title: Lidar Maker Hesai Is Said to Confidentially File for Hong Kong Listing
item.description: China’s Hesai Group, the world’s largest maker of lidar sensors used in driver assistance systems, has confidentially filed for a Hong Kong listing, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Julia Fioretti, Amanda Wang

media:content.media:description: Cameras and lidar sensors on an Inceptio Technology autonomous truck in Jinan, Shandong Province, China, on Thursday, April 18, 2024. While most attention on the development of autonomous driving has focused on passenger cars — like Tesla's controversial Full Self-Driving — Chinese startup Inceptio Technology is concentrating on revolutionizing long-haul trucking. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
